Hi
  Checking if a new individual is an isomorph graph of
on of the previous individual would be the ultimate
answer... At least at the beginning of the evolution,
where there is few graph isomorphisms.
  Sadly, checking if two graphs are isomorphs is both
an expensive and difficult task if you don't pick a
particular familly of graphs, like planar graphs. You
can check if two graphs are isomorph by using a simple
backtracking algorithm, but it's slow if you need
complex graphs...

--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> a ï¿½crit :

> We may address it in future experiments in order to
> speed them up, 
> but I probably would not make it the focus of a
> publication because 
> its solution is likely fairly straightforward, i.e.
> not that deep in 
> a research sense. Also, the problem of revisiting
> the same points is 
> known in stochastic algorithms already.
> 
> The most obvious way to address the problem is
> simply to compare 
> new genomes with what's come before.  Of course,
> such comparisons 
> become increasingly expensive as the generations
> increase, and at 
> some point, it becomes cheaper simply to evaluate
> everyone rather 
> than try to figure out who is a repeat.  Depending
> on available 
> resources, you can program it to look for duplicates
> as long as it's 
> computationally advantageous.  It may turn out not
> very useful for 
> most of the run.
> 
> There is a potential for more sophisticated
> appraches, e.g. maybe 
> some kind of hashing scheme, but they would need to
> promise 
> sufficiently impressive results to justify their
> effort.  I am not 
> sure how much effort is justified by a 10%
> improvement.  I am 
> guessing work has been done on this problem before
> outside of NEAT, 
> but I don't know about it offhand.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Rafael C.P."
> <kurama.youko.br@...> 
> wrote:
> >
> > Any plan for addressing this issue in a future
> paper and/or 
> implementation?
> > 
> > On Nov 26, 2007 12:23 PM, Kenneth Stanley
> <kstanley@...> wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > Andy, thanks for pointing this issue out. Those
> are interesting
> > >  statistics. It is indeed best to avoid
> reevaluating an organism 
> that
> > >  is the same as one that has come before. 10% is
> not terrible 
> but it
> > >  does mean evolution could have been even
> faster.
> > >
> > >  ken
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >  --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2"
> <a.carl@> wrote:
> > >  >
> > >  > Investigation of redundant organisms in NEAT
> using standard 
> param
> > >  > values has shown an approximate 10 percent
> redundancy factor 
> as
> > >  follows:
> > >  >
> > >  > Population Size: 100
> > >  > Number Outputs: 10 (i.e. 10-dimensional
> coordinate space)
> > >  > Distance Tolerance: 1.0E-6 (in non-normalized
> coordinates)
> > >  >
> > >  > Duplicates in Generation 1 were ignored.
> > >  >
> > >  > "A" = Generation Number
> > >  > "B" = Cum # of Redundant Organisms (i.e. less
> than tol 
> distance
> > >  apart)
> > >  > "C" = Total Number of Organisms Evaluated
> > >  >
> > >  > "A","B","C"
> > >  > 1,0,100
> > >  > 2,8,200
> > >  > 3,17,300
> > >  > 4,30,400
> > >  > 5,44,500
> > >  > 6,56,600
> > >  > 7,65,700
> > >  > 8,76,800
> > >  > 9,94,900
> > >  > 10,115,1000
> > >  >
> > >  > In instances in which the fitness
> computational requirements 
> are
> > >  non-
> > >  > trivial, screening and fitness substitution
> for redundant 
> organisms
> > >  is
> > >  > justified. The issues of search space
> coverage and variaion 
> with
> > >  param
> > >  > value changes were not addressed.
> > >  >
> > >  > ( Reference Resource: ANN: A Library for
> Approximate Nearest
> > >  Neighbor
> > >  > Searching, Mount, David M., Arya, Sunil,
> > >  > http://www.cs.umd.edu/~mount/ANN/ )
> > >  >
> > >
> > >
